And you, Virginians, who are laboring to save the honor and independence of the Commonwealth, are thus denounced from the shadow of Lincoln's throne as "conspirators" against the " Future of White Labor in the South," or in other words against the Abolition of Slavery.--What a confession!
What a warning!
This, then, is the alternative — Secession and Slave Labor; or, the Union and White Labor!

div3.head: Suicide from Jealousy.
div3.p:
--Mrs. Caroline King, of New York, who had been married two weeks, found a lady's glove in the pocket of her husband, who is an actor, and on Monday took poison, leaving a note on the bed near her body, stating that if he loved any one better than her she did not want to live.
She had taken corrosive sublimate.
continues to take Photographs and Ambrotypes, in his usual exquisite style, at panic prices $50 style reduced to $30; $15 to $10; $8 to $5; $3 to $1.50; $2 to $1; 50 cents and 25 cents.

Babies taken correctly.
mn 12--3t

div4.p: On Tuesday, the 12th inst., after a lingering illness, at her residence, on Union Hill, Mrs. Adeline McCOOK, consort of the late James McCook, in the 41st year of her age having a family of eight orphan children to mourn their irreparable loss.
The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, to-day, the 14th inst., at 10 o'clock A. M., without further notice.

On Tuesday, the 12th of March, after a protracted illness.
Madame Caroline H. Vassus, a native of France.

Through a mistake, an obituary that was to appear yesterday morning, was not published.-- This statement is necessary, to prove that the expression of our admiration for the deceased is not the result of a long reflection, but the prompt and sincere cry of friends distressed by the death of Madame Caroline H. Vassus. Indeed, she possessed qualities calculated to draw all hearts.-- She was obliging, kind, active to serve her friends — pions, without bigotry.
How many times did her witty remarks charm our leisure moments!
How many times did her excellent heart find comfort for our afflictions!
How many times were not our sad thoughts made sweet by the idea of her intelligent piety; of her entire, unlimited, unmeasurable self-denial; of her devotion to her daughter!
Such an example of maternal love may be equalled, but cannot be surpassed.
Object of all her cares and of all her actions, subject of all her thoughts, her daughter was the occupation of all her life.
She consecrated all the strength of her heart and body to the happiness and comfort of her whose reciprocal love was the sweet reward of her touching and incessant devotion-- and still she found in her heart some affection for her friends, to whom, in the sorrow which overwhelms them, one only consolation is left — the one allowed by the remembrance of her pious and virtuous life — the hope that her soul is now enjoying the sight of its Maker. (*) A Friend.
On Tuesday, March 12th, 1861, at a quarter to 9 o'clock P. M., Mollie A., only child of John W. and Mary S. Garrett, in the 7th year of her age.
God hath taken our little idol home to Heaven.

div3.head: Twenty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway about the 10th of January last, a Negro Man named Archy Todd.
Said Negro is about 20 years old, medium size, very black, large eyes, bushy head, and very slovenly in his dress.
Was hired to Mr. B. W. Green last year.
Part of the time drove mules.
I will give the above reward for his delivery to me.

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p:
--One of my servants, named Robert James, ran off on Thursday last.
He is a Ditcher, exclusively, and took off his tools with him, with a view doubtless to obtain work on his own account, to which he had been accustomed before I purchased him. I will pay the above reward for his apprehension and delivery to me.

div3.head: $25 reward.
div3.p: --Ranaway from the subscriber, about the middle of January, my Man "Manuel. " Said negro is about five feet ten inches in height, bushy head of hair, and a very dark mulatto, and has a slight impediment in his speech when spoken to. Said negro is believed to be lurking about Atlee's Station, in Hanover county, or about Richmond.-- The above reward will be paid for his apprehension and delivery to me in Richmond, or Hanover Jail, or to D. R. Jones, in King William co., Va.
div3.closer:
Thos. Doswell,
Junction P. O., Hanover co., Va. mh 1--1m

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 19, Number 61, page 3.

div2.head:
Thursday morning..March 14, 1861.
from Charleston.
[special Correspondence of the Dispatch.]

div3.p:
A dispatch received here to-day from Washington announced that Fort Sumter would be evacuated on Wednesday.
It was not believed, and a dispatch was immediately sent off, and, in answer just received, it is confirmed asthe policy of the Administration.--We do not learn that it is the policy of the Administration to give up all the forts in the Southern Confederacy, or merely the one in our harbor, which they could neither reinforce or maintain, If it be true that they have ordered an evacuation, I am personally profoundly glad, as I have not the least relish for the smell of gunpowder; but it is a wonderful disappointment to many here, I assure you. If, however, Sumter is to be given up, and the forts on the Florida coast are to be held by the United States Government, our soldiers will have a fair opportunity to display their gallantry, and they will do it to a moral certainly.
The evacuation is to take place on Wednesday, according to the Courier's dispatches just received.

The fifteen million loan of the Southern Confederacy has been taken in New Orleans, at five per cent. premium.
No mistake.
I should not be surprised, after a little, if money does not become so plenty that any note will sell at a premium, if drawn payable in the Southern Confederacy.

I heard not long since a public speaker, who had been badly abused by certain other parties, put his case in this wise: I was passing over the Georgia Railroad on yesterday, and as the iron-horse went snorting and tearing over the road with eight passenger cars dragging at its tail, at the rate of forty miles an hour, in passing a house on the road a little carl-tail cur put at the train, yelping at every jump, gnashing his teeth with very rage, and, after spending his breath in his fruitless effort, he gave up and laid down to rest, mortified with himself, no doubt, that he had made himself so ridiculous.
Ask those gentlemen who abuse South Carolina, if anything strikes them?
Winter weather to-day, and as it is Monday, and not in a very good humor, I will say no more to-night, but reserve some interesting matters to be written and thought of tomorrow, perhaps.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
man lost, and found Dead — crops — large
bullocks.
div3.p:
John Freed, an old gentleman of this county, aged about 80 or 81 years, (supposed to be the "oldest inhabitant" of Brock's Gap, in this county,) who resided near the head of the Shenandoah river, in the "Gap," started, on the 23d of February, to go to John Wratsford's, on the top of the mountain, about seven miles distant, on an errand, and it seems he lost his way. He started on the 23d of February, as before stated, but no search was made for him until the Thursday following, when a company of twenty-eight men started to look for him. On the 1st day of March the company all met at Mr. Carter's, and started on the hunt.
They first searched Moyer's Mountain; next, search was made in Gable (or Gobble) Mountain, and across to the Spruckelick Hollow, and down to the Cold Spring Run, through Cold Spring Hollow, at which point they took the sun side of the Shenandoah Mountain, and when about half-way they found where the old man had been sitting, by the side of a linn tree.--He had broken off the brush around him, and set up a pole some six feet high.
From there they saw no sign of him, until they found him about 75 yards distant from the linn tree.
When found, his face was dreadfully bruised, and his right arm broken.
He had been sitting, so supposed, on a large flat rock, from which he had fallen.
He was all doubled up, and had fallen on his forehead.
His hands were also bruised.
No one can imagine the sufferings this poor old man endured, whilst wandering in those wild mountain gorges, without food or shelter.
Whether he died from the falls, which his bruises indicate, or from starvation, God alone knows.
He had been a soldier in the war of1812, and received a pension for his services.
He had been in the habit, for years, of wandering alone in the mountains, always returning safely, which doubtless failed to awaken earlier alarm, or led to a search for him. He was a quiet, harmless old man, and left an intelligent family to mourn his sad fate.

After diligent inquiry, I hear that the wheat is looking very fine in all sections of this and adjoining counties.
It is to be hoped we will have a plentiful supply of wheat this season, as also corn and other crops, which will probably do wonders in relieving our people during the present crisis.
Real estate does not command its value, for the reason just given — i. e., money is too scarce.
Our Banks here are of no benefit to the people, as they seem to operate upon the principle of "keeping all they have got, and getting all they can."

I had the pleasure of a short trip through the country a few days since.
I called at the residence of Dr. B. F. Walker, near Mount Meridian, in Augusta county, where I saw the largest, fattest, and in every respect the finest lot of cattle I ever beheld.
There were only twenty- six of them — but worth one hundred of the common kind.
The Doctor, who always keeps fine stock about him, thinks they will average 1,700 or 1,800 lbs.--I put them at more.
He intends sending them to Richmond in April, and you can well afford to "lick your chops, " in anticipation of such a fine feast of the finest quality of "roast beef. "--Being extra cattle, I hope the Doctor may obtain the highest figures, as a reward for his exertion in thus preparing such fine bullocks for market.
He is not only "all right" on the cattle, but he takes the Dispatch, and believes it teaches the true doctrine, and is ready to stand up to the same.

For several days past, large numbers of preachers, belonging to the Baltimore Conference, have been passing on their way to Staunton, to attend the meeting of that body, which commences to- morrow.
This will be, probably, the most important session of this body ever yet held.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
public meeting in Petersburg.
div3.p:
The call for a meeting of "all who are in favor of constitutional liberty, and the Union as our fathers formed it," was responded to, last night, by one of the largest political assemblages ever convened in this city.
The special object of this call was to take the sense of the people upon the important question of instructing our delegate (Mr. Branch) to vote for the immediate secession of Virginia.
From the result of this meeting, it is evident that each party intended to have an equal voice in the proceedings — to applaud or condemn, is the case might be. At an early hour crowds wended their way to the Hall, and truly a highly exciting programme was in reserve for them.
Wm.T. Joynes, Esq., presided, and Messrs. A. F. Crutchfield and John Lyon acted as Secretaries.
Mr. C. F. Collier our representative in the Legislature, offered a series of resolutions in favor of immediate secession, assigning causes with which all are familiar, and ending with instructions to Mr. Branch to act in accordance with them.
He sustained these resolutions by eloquent remarks in defence of his position.

A substitute was offered by Mr. G. W. Bolling, setting forth the inexpediency of any instruction, and in favor of leaving Mr. B. untrammeled in the exercise of his own judgment.
Messrs. Bolling, Pryor, and Lyon, each addressed the audience; and between the two last there occurred an exciting debate, which at one time it was feared, would cause some hostile action.

During the whole of these proceedings, noise and confusion reigned to such an extent that all definite action was impossible, and it was hard to believe that this assemblage was composed of our most respectable and intelligent citizens.
At this important crisis, when calmness and moderation should prevail in our councils, and men should remember that "fair play is a jewel," courtesy is completely lost sight of, and we recall the noisy clamor of school boys engaged in pet discussions.

A third resolution, proposing that a poll should be opened for three successive days, to take the vote of the whole city upon the question, was finally introduced, and passed by a considerable majority, after which the meeting adjourned.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
public meeting in Meeklenburg.
div3.p:
A meeting was held in this place last Friday, to take into consideration the alarming state of the country and especially the State of Virginia. Capt Robert Y. Overby presided, and John G. Boyd acted as Secretary.
The preamble of the resolutions passed by the meeting sets forth that Virginia having failed to inaugurate peace, through the instrumentality of the so- called Peace Congress, it is indisputable hat the dominant party do not intend to give the South the just rights demanded; that the seceded States have no idea of returning to the late Union; that the "Franklin Compromise" leaves matters worse than before, and that Lincoln's Inaugural is, in fact, a declaration of war against the South.
The first resolution declares it the honor, dignity and best interest of Virginia to resume at once the powers delegated to the General Government.
The second says that Virginia should join the South, and our delegate is requested to urge upon the Convention prompt action.
The third repudiates me "Franklin substitute," and endorses the speech lately delivered by Col. Goode.
The fourth sends the resolutions to Colonel Goode, with the request that they be laid before the Convention.
The people are moving.

The tobacco factories have just commenced work.
The weather is clear and cold.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
things in Suffolk and Nansemond.
div3.p:
Your correspondent, "Todd," not having enlightened the public concerning our affairs for some time, a new scribbler begs leave now to perform that important duty.
Our delegate to the Convention, Mr. John R. Kilby, our member in the Legislature, spent the Sabbath with his family in this place, and on yesterday, that being Court day, "reported progress" to his constituents in a speech nearly two hours long.
Mr. K. Assured his fellow-citizens that, not withstanding the serious apprehensions which had filled the public mind a short time back, yet, through the mediation of Virginia, there was "nobody hurt. " He said he should endeavor to do his duty, and see to it that Virginia should not be tacked on to "the tail of the Southern Confederacy."--Your correspondent deeply regrets to add that the speech was loudly applauded by a Nansemond audience.
But while Mr. K. fairly represents the views of the large majority of our county men, yet there are several of our most prominent and wealthy citizens preparing to secede, individually, with their household and kitchen furniture, to a more congenial, social atmosphere; fearing, with your correspondent, that in view of recent events, the State, as such, has already become abolitionized, and believing that not even your able and strenuous efforts will avail to save her.

Several volunteer companies have been formed of late in this county, all of which are doomed to a temporary existence, and that, too, without arms; for "the law," as laid down in the Chicago platform, by which Virginia must now abide, is, that "the majority must rule," and that the minority, however respectable, has just exactly no rights at all.

The "Christian" Church in this place was dedicated on Sunday last.
There was a very large crowd of town and country people present, and the sum of $300 was collected with which to pay a debt of $1200; but I presume that, in the end, "nobody'll be hurt."
Thus the world wags with us at present, and as for your correspondent, he sits and sings all day--

p.q: "I wish I was in Dixie, away down Souf."

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
affairs in Fredericksburg.
div3.p:
Yesterday was what may be termed truly a remarkable day in the annals of the city of Fredericksburg.
During the morning and early part of the day, there were to be seen curious gatherings of the principal citizens at the corners, discussing, as is supposed, the Inaugural of Abraham Lincoln, particularly that portion in which he says the revenue must be collected and the Federal property preserved.
Towards noon crowds of the leading gentlemen of this place gathered together in the neighborhood of the Corn Exchange, and, upon repairing to the spot, we found that a flag of the Southern Confederacy was to be raised, which at 6 o'clock was, amid prolific and hearty cheering, loosed to the influences of a Southern breeze.
The scene I shall never forget.
Stentorian lungs of rustic yeomen, feeble attempts of city men, and the voices of the elite of the town, were lent to swell the sound of joy. Everything moved on in the most perfect harmony, and nothing occurred to mar the enjoyment of the evening.
At half-past 7 o'clock the bell of the City Hall commenced ringing.
We went there and found, to our surprise, the Unionists were going to have a meeting.
At eight o'clock the meeting was called to order, and Hugh Scott, Esq., being called to the Chair, and John F. Alexander appointed Secretary, a committee was appointed to draft resolution and during their absence, G. H. C. Rowen Esq., being called upon to address the meeting, did so, spreading to the winds his sentiments, which were for secession.
At the conclusion of his speech the committee was called upon to report, and upon making known to the meeting that their votes were desired upon the resolutions favoring the Union, the resolutions were voted down by an overwhelming majority.

Secession is raging in the minds of many here, and is on the increase.
Scarcely a man can be found who does not desire a dissolution under any circumstances.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
trial,&c.
div3.p:
The trial of young Addison Logan, for killing Kent Anderson, terminated last Saturday, after lasting a week, on the acquittal of the former.
It was a most interesting and important trial, and attracted great attention.--The prosecution was conducted by John J. Wade, an able and indefatigable prosecutor.--The defence was conducted by Waller Staples, Robert Trigg, William Watts, and James C. Taylor, and was managed with consummate skill and adroitness.
There is considerable diversity of opinion in regard to the judgment of the Court.
The defence was accidental homicide, and was argued on that point with eminent success and ability.

The secession feeling is gaining ground here very rapidly.
The crooked policy of the Black Republicans is fast alienating the staunchest friends of the Union.
There is some talk of calling a meeting of the people of the county, with a view of getting a formal expression of sentiment in regard to the future policy of the State.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
destructive fire in Lynchburg.
div3.p:
A fire broke out this morning, about half-past 3 o'clock, in Smith's ten-pin alley, 110 Main street, (rear building,) and is now raging fearfully, and threatens to be very destructive.
Several kitchens and out-buildings have already been consumed.
The tin manufactory of J. M. Price, and the shoemaking establishment of J. O. Thomas, are now burning rapidly, and the fire has communicated to a large brick building on Market street. The banking house of Messrs. Peters, Williams & Co., auction house of Bryan Akers, merchant tailoring establishment of P. McDevitt, and commission house of Clark & Holt, are seriously threatened, the rear buildings having been already consumed.
The firemen are making every exertion, but the fire has gained such headway that they have not been able to give it a material check up to this hour, (5 A. M.)

div3.head: Young lady shot.
div3.p:
--In Baltimore, on Tuesday, Philip J. Coakley, while drunk in the street, fired on a policeman who interfered to keep him quiet, shooting him through the breast.
One of the balls struck Miss Susan Williams, a school girl, passing by, and inflicted a dangerous wound just above her ankle, which may cripple her for life.

div3.head: A Shocking Catastrophe.
div3.p:
--The Prairi (Miss.) News states that on the night of the 2d instant a negro woman, a slave to S. P. Gates, went to a dance in a neighboring house, leaving her five little children locked up in her dwelling.
During her absence her house got on fire, and, before assistance arrived, the poor children were all burned to death.

div3.head: Death of an editor.
div3.p: --Thomas L. Wilson, formerly a well known citizen of Virginia, died in Harrisburg, Penn., on the 8th of March, in the 61st year of his age. For a period of ten years, from 1825 to 1835, he was editor of the Petersburg Intelligencer, and in 1836 he was editor of the Democrat, published in Lynchburg at that time.

div3.head: The North Carolina Commissioners.
div3.p:
--The Hons.
D. M. Barringer, David S. Reid, George Davis, Thomas Ruffin, and J. M. Morehead, the Commissioners from North Carolina to the late Peace Conference, have presented a report to Governor Ellis, of their State, reciting substantially the same facts contained in the report of the Virginia Commissioners.

div3.head: Secession in Kentucky.
div3.p: --The Kentucky Secessionists have issued a circular, advising the immediate institution of measures in all the counties of the State for the election of delegates to a Convention, to be held at Frankfort on the 20th of the present month.

div3.head: Michigan Personal Liberty bill.
div3.p: --After an animated debate, the Michigan House of Delegates has indefinitely postponed the consideration of the bill for the repeal of the Personal Liberty law, by a vote of 43 against 24.

div3.head: Lottery policies in New York.
div3.p: --It is stated that the venders of lottery policies in New York draw from the poor of that city over $900,000 per annum, Philadelphia, it is thought, spends nearly as much in policy gambling.

div3.head: Fire.
div3.p:
--Rose Hill, the residence of Peter R. Thornton, in Caroline co., Va., was entirely consumed by fire about 12 o'clock on Wednesday.
Nothing was saved.
Loss about $4,000. No insurance.
The fire was accidental.
General Twiggs declares that the Government shall not reverse its decision against him. He considers it as being the cause of the most distinguished honors ever conferred upon him.
Governor Magoffin, of Kentucky, had his left arm broken at its socket on Sunday last, by the upsetting of a stage coach at Harrodsburg.

Seventeen men are stated to have been seriously poisoned, recently, by drinking tea, in Wisconsin.
A lizard's body was found in the tea-kettle.
A woman of forty-two, Anna Marston, attended the funeral of her eighth husband in Portsmouth, England, on the 13th ult.
Archibald Campbell, editor of the Wheeling Intelligencer, has been nominated for postmaster at that place.
The lights at Mobile Point and Sand Island have been extinguished by order of the commander of Fort Morgan.
Joshua Lee was killed in Wirt county, Va., last week, by a blow alleged to have been given by his son-in-law, named Dolan.
The journals of Turin announce the death of Colatta Marchioani, one of the most celebrated dramatic artists of the age.
Eugene Sinbe, the dramatist, died in his carriage, of apoplexy.

div3.head: Extra session of the U. S. Senate.
div3.p: Washington,March 13.--Mr. Douglas offered a resolution asking information as to what forts, arsenals, navy-yards, and other public property in the limits of the seceded States, are now in actual possession of the United States; the number of men of each garrison; whether reinforcements are necessary to retain them; if the Government has the power and means, under existing laws, within the necessary time, whether it is necessary and wise to reinforce them, with the exception of Tortugas and Key West, and to recapture those seized by the seceding States, except with a view to the subjugation and occupation of those States; and if such be the motive for recapture, what force, regular and volunteer, is necessary to reduce them to subjection, and protect the Federal States.--The resolution lies over.
Mr. Fessenden moved a resolution to strike from the roll of the Senate the names of Messrs. Benjamin, Brown, Davis, Mallory, Clay and Toombs--lies over.
The Senate then went into Executive session.

div3.head: From the Southern Capital.
div3.p: Montgomery, Ala.,March 13.--The Congress will, it is believed, take a recess during this week.

Speaker Cobb has sent to the different States of the Confederation copies of the permanent Constitution.
The Alabama Convention received it to-day, and will, it is expected, ratify it to-morrow.
[second Dispatch.]

The Tariff act is published.
It goes into operation on the 1st of May. Compared with the United States tariff, most of the 30 per cent. duties are reduced to 25 per cent., a greater portion to 24 per cent., and the 19 per cent. duties are reduced to 15.
There is a large 10 per cent. schedule, and a very small free list.
The Alabama Convention ratified the permanent Constitution by a vote of 87 to 5.-- Gen. Jamison, a leading co-operationist, took a bold position in favor of the ratification.
Jere Clemens is appointed Major General of the Alabama army.

div3.head: From Washington.
div3.p: Washington,March 13.--The object of Senator Douglas' resolution in the Senate, was to officially disclose the fact that there is no adequate power to retake and hold the forts in the seceded States, and that more would be required, and the attempt therefore must be postponed until the meeting of Congress.
Col. Sumner has been nominated to the Senate Brigadier General vice Twiggs.
The order is not yet issued to evacuate Fort Sumter.

Mr. Douglas will address the Senate on his resolution to-morrow.
He will lay down three propositions, comprising only one which will present any complications.
The first proposition offers such amendments to the Constitution as will guarantee the seceded States their rights and bring them back; the second, recognizing their independence and forming a commercial treaty with them; third, a war of subjugation, to be followed by military occupation.
These he considers the three horns of the dilemma.
He considers the first the best, and the last the worst.

Commissioners Forsyth and Crawford have received such assurances from high sources of the pacific intention of the Administration in reference to the Southern forts that at present they will make no official demand.
Pending the movements looking to the evacuation of Fort Sumter, they will remain quiet.

div3.head:
From Georgia.
Augusta, Ga.,March 13.
div3.p:
--The reported seizure by Gov. Brown, of stock held by Northern citizens in the Georgia Railroad, is incorrect.
The President of the road denies its truth.
Savannah,March 13.--The State Convention has transferred the forts, arsenals, arms, &c., in Georgia, to the Confederate States.
An ordinance was passed appropriating $500,000 to the support of the General Government, and authorizing the Governor of Georgia to issue bonds to that amount.

div3.head: New Hampshire election.
div3.p: Concord, N. H.,March 12.--The annual election for State officers and members of Congress is in progress to-day.
The returns do not show a large vote, and there is very little excitement.
As far as heard from, the Republicans maintain about the same majority as last year.

In Concord, the vote in four wards at 1 o'clock stood--Republican 631, Opposition 375.
About the same as last year.
[second Dispatch.]

Concord,March 13.--Berry, Rep., is elected Governor by a majority of 4,000.
All the Republican candidates are elected to Congress.

div3.head: The vote in Petersburg.
div3.p: Petersburg,March 13.-- 2 P. M. --The vote on the Secession Resolutions, submitted at the meeting on Monday night, is progressing.--Secession is 110 ahead, and the Union strength is nearly exhausted.
[second Dispatch.]
Petersburg,March 13.--The vote to- night at dark showed the secessionists 51 ahead, and this majority is expected to be increased during the following to-morrow.

The secession men are parading the streets with a band.
A great crowd is out and will be addressed by Messrs. Pryor, String fellow and others, onPoplar Lawn, at 8 o'clock.

div3.head: From California.
div3.p:
Fort Kearney,March 12.--Dates from San Francisco are to the 27th.
Nothing important.

The Legislature met on the 26th.
In the caucus of the friends of Ex-Gov. Denvers for Senator, they mustered only 54.
It requires 58 to elect.

div3.head: Naval.
div3.p:
Norfolk,March 13.--The U. S. steamer Pocahontas, from Vera Cruz, arrived in Hampton Roads last evening.
The Cumberland is hourly expected.
New York,March 13.--A steam frigate is coming up — probably the Powhatan, from Vera Cruz.

div3.head: Fire in Lynchburg.
div3.p: Lynchburg, Va.,March 13. --A fire took place here last night, destroying Williams & Peters' brokers' office, and several other buildings.

div3.head: Municipal election.
div3.p: Bangor, Me.,March 12th.--At the municipal election yesterday, Isaiah Stetson, Republican, was re-elected Mayor by 750 majority.

div3.head: Northern Markets.
div3.p:
New York,March 13.--Cotton firm — uplands middling 11¼@11½.
Flour firm.
Wheat has a declining tendency.
Corn has a declining tendency — mixed 59@67; Southern white.
70@ 71; yellow 63@68 Pork heavy — mess $16.87@18; prime steady at $12.50 @13.
Lard heavy at 9@9½c Whiskey steady.
Sugar heavy — Muscovado 4½ @5--Coffee steady.
Molasses unchanged.
Turpentine steady at 36½c. Rosin heavy at $1.23. Rice steady.
Stocks heavy — New York Centrals 78½; Virginia 6's 78¼; Missouri 6's 66¼.
Sales in New York,March 12th, of $6, 000 Tennessee 6's at $75½; $8,000 do. at $75¼; $5,000 do. at $75½; $23,000 do. at $75; $1,000 North Carolina 6's at $32, and $1,000 do, at $81½.

Baltimore,March 13.--Flour dull and heavy — Howard and Ohio $5; City Mills $5; no buyers.--Wheat active — Red $1.23 @1.27; White $1.45@1.65 Corn has a declining tendency and is 2 cent 2 lower — Mixed 63@65.
Provisions dull and unchanged.
Coffee firm at 12¼@13.
Whiskey dull at 18 cents.

div2.head:
Auction Sales.
Future days.
by I. & G. B. Davenport, Auct'rs.

Auction Sales.
Future days.
by A. D. Williness, Auct's.

div3.head: By Hector Davis, Auct'r.
div3.p:
Trustee's Sale of valuable Slaves at Auction.--As Trustee in a deed of trust dated December 13th, 1860. and recorded in the Clerk's Office of the Hustings Court of the city of Richmond, and at the request of the creditors secured in said deed, I shall proceed to sell, at the Auction Rooms of Hector Davis, in the city of Richmond, at the hour of 10 o'clock, on Monday, the 18th day of March, 1861, six valuable Slaves, said Slaves constituting the portions of personal estate conveyed to me in said deed.--These Slaves consist of four Men, who are all young and active, one Boy about 16 years of age, and a valuable Woman.
Terms.--Cash.

div2.head:
Auction Sales.
Future days.
by James M. Taylor & son, Auct'rs.

Auction Sales
this day.
by alexander Nott, Auct'r.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 19, Number 61, page 4.

div3.head: A hand-cart emigrant to Pike's Peak.
div3.p: --A correspondent, writing from Denver City to the St. Louis Republican, relates the following:

q.p:
"I know a young man in Lawrence, Kansas, not yet of age, who left that city in company with a boy much younger than himself.
It was about the time so many were returning, pronouncing our mineral researches a monstrous humbug.
This couple of gold adventurers pushed out of Lawrence en route for this place.
All they possessed in the world was packed into a rather rickety hand-cart.
They pushed it on before them, camping under it at night, until they reached Fort Riley, where the younger of the two became discouraged by the reports of its being all a delusion and a humbug, repeated to him every hour almost by the returning adventurers, and concluded to return.
All his efforts to induce his traveling companion to accompany him back were of no avail; and there, on the wide prairie, those two parted company, one to return to his home, the other to push his hand-cart before him until he reached the mountains.

"After encountering many difficulties and delays, occasioned by break-downs, he at last reached his destination.
He came into the mountains, took up some claims, sold some, purchased others, went on to the States last fall, found a gentleman with whom he formed a copartnership, bought a quartz mill, and last spring brought it out and set it up here.
The mill proved to be the worst constructed piece of machinery ever brought to these mines, and has since been laid aside as useless.
The young man has recently sold his interest in the old mill, and his claims on the Fisk Lode for something over $11,000 cash.--He still has valuable gold claims here."

div3.p:
--A letter from Guerero, Mexico, tells something of a new Saint, who is creating a great excitement at Mier, about ten miles distant from that place.
It says:

q.p: "Fancy a man, about 60 years of age, very dark and vulgar looking, with a long white beard, reaching half way to his waist, grey moustache and hair, with a hat of the old high- crowned, broad brim Mexican style black wool, a coat of striped sackcloth, pants of the same, a dirty white shirt, open down the bosom, sandals on a pair of very dirty feet, tied with strings coming up between the toes, and you have the personnel of a man who wields a rod of iron over about 2,000 human beings, and they following him and kissing his feet and hands, and firmly believing him to be the God of Hosts.

"I was with him all day — took supper with him, and had some conversation with him. I asked him about peace in Mexico and the U. States.
He said there never would be peace again, in either country, until the world was destroyed.
His mode of doctoring is curious.
His medicines are 'aqua ardiente' and water.
He rubs it on the affected parts while the patient is kneeling.
He has performed some astonishing cures, and supports the people who are with him. He buys beeves, divides amongst them, gives them clothing, and supports them entirely.
Where the money comes from I do not know; but I do know that he supports them, and at an enormous expense.
This is no hearsay what I have said.
I have seen, and unless I had, would not believe."

div3.p:
--Now that King Francis and his family have quitted Naples, there are in exile not fewer than fifty-five members of the Bourbon family out of the seventy-four who are the direct or collateral descendants of Louis XIV.
The fifty-five are these: The Bourbons of Naples, consisting of King Francis, five brothers and four sisters; his Majesty's uncles--Prince de Capua and two children, Count d' Aquila and two children, Count de Trapani and five; his Majesty's aunts--Queen Marie Amelia, widow of King Louis Phillippe; the Duchess de Berry, and the Duchess de Salerno, and, lastly, a cousin german, the Duchess d' Aumale — total 26.
The Bourbons of Spain — the Infante Don Juan and two children — total, 3.
The Bourbons of France--Count de Chambord, the Duchess de Parma and four children — total, 6.
The Orleans branch of the French Bourbons--the Count de Paris, the Duke de Chartres, the Duke de Nemours and four children, the Prince de Joinville and two, the Duke de Aumale and two, the Duke de Montpensier and six--total, 20. Nineteen Bourbons are not in exile — namely, the royal family of Spain, 16 in number; the Empress of Brazil, (nee Princess of Naples;) the Duchess Augustus of Saxe-Coburg Gotha, (nee Princess d' Orleans;) and the Duke Charles III.
of Parma, Infante of Spain, who abdicated.

div3.head: A Cure for Slippery Sidewalks.
div3.p: --The Niagara Falls Gazette tells a story of two young ladies who were promenading along the street recently, when one of them slipped and came down on the icy pavement "like a thousand of bricks." Jumping quickly up, she exclaimed, sotto voce, "Before another winter I'll have a man to hang to; see if I don't!"
Davis, Deupree & Co. will give their entire attention to the Sale of negroes, Publicly and privately.
Odd Fellows' Hall, Corner Mayo and Franklin streets, Richmond, Va.

div3.head: To Farmers.--Negro Shoes.
div3.p:
--Farmers and others wanting Negro Shoes are invited to call at No. 92 Main street, where will be found the largest and best assortment ever offered in Richmond.
My assortment embraces, 2,000 pairs of heavy Sewed Brogans, of my own make; Men's Army Brogans.
Men's high-out do., very thick, nailed with hob nails; Dane's best thick pegged Brogans; Her rick's best thick pegged Brogans; Planters' and Dutch Boots for women, together with all other grades, suitable for servants, men, women and boys.
Farmers will do well to give me a call, at No. 93 Main str.
